Reading reversed runes, much like reversed tarot cards, adds depth and nuance to your practice. When a rune appears upside down or in a reversed position during a reading, its meaning can shift, often highlighting challenges, blockages, delays, obstacles, or a need to reevaluate the situation.

Not all runes are traditionally read in their reversed form. The Elder Futhark, the most commonly used runic alphabet, and the alphabet we use in this app, consists of 24 runes. Of these, 8 can never be reversed, though some traditions may vary this number. It is said that this is often based on whether the rune is symmetrical vertically; some runes, like Gebo, Ingwaz, Eihwaz, and Dagaz, look the same whether upright or reversed.

While reversed runes often signal challenges or warnings, they can also provide valuable insights into areas of life that need attention, offering guidance on how to overcome obstacles or shift perspectives. Lifeâ€™s path is rarely straightforward, and as with the tarot, we must explore both light and shadow.
rune-reverse.subtitle: The Role of Symmetry
rune-reverse.title: Reading Reversed Runes

swords.content:
The swords is the suit of intelligence, logic, truth, ambition, conflict and communication. It is associated with the element of air. In readings, these cards focus on the faculty and power of intellect, which like the swords themselves, are double-edged. This can be used for both good or evil, to help and to harm, and our greatest conflicts usually come from this delicate balance.

At their worst, the swords can be abusive, harsh, and lack empathy.
swords.subtitle: Intellect, logic, communication, conflict and analysis
swords.title: The Suit of Swords

tarot-astro.content:
After mastering the basic keywords for each card, deeper levels of meaning can be found if you choose to explore the astrological concepts associated with each card, particularly if you already have a basic understanding of astrology.

In western astrology, there are 12 zodiac signs and 10 celestial bodies used to read our astrological charts. These happen to correspond with the 22 Major Arcana in tarot. This chart is also color coded to show the card's element. As we discussed in an earlier article, the element of the card is based on the astrological body's element.

0. Fool
Uranus
1. Magician
Mercury
2. High Priestess
Moon
3. Empress
Venus
4. Emperor
Aries
5. Hierophant
Taurus
6. Lovers
Gemini
7. Chariot
Cancer
8. Strength
Leo
9. Hermit
Virgo
10. Wheel of Fortune
Jupiter
11. Justice
Libra
12. Hanged Man
Neptune
13. Death
Scorpio
14. Temperance
Sagittarius
15. Devil
Capricorn
16. Tower
Mars
17. Star
Aquarius
18. Moon
Pisces
19. Sun
Sun
20. Judgement
Pluto
21. World
Saturn


You'll see that the zodiac signs fall in a loose order, while the planets seem to be randomly scattered across the list.

These are the easy ones to remember. The Minor Arcana correspondences will need a much more advanced understanding of astrological concepts that cannot be covered here (Labyrinthos is a tarot app, after all!), but we still include the quizzes here should you choose to use them.
tarot-astro.subtitle: The easy stuff: planets, zodiac signs and the Major Arcana
tarot-astro.title: Major Arcana & Astrology Correspondences

tarot-elements.content:
You may have already guessed from the artwork that each suit of the Minor Arcana corresponds with one of the four elements:

Wands
Fire
Cups
Water
Swords
Air
Pentacles
Earth


The only slightly tricky ones to remember are those of the Major Arcana. If you are already familiar with western astrology, remember that you can get the element of the Major Arcana card by getting its planet's or zodiac sign's element. For example, the astrological correspondence of the Strength card is Leo. Leo's element is fire, so Strength's element is also fire.

You can use elements to get an understanding of the main themes in your readings. An abundance of cups can signal the importance of relationships and emotions, while swords can signal that matters of conflict and logic play a big role.
tarot-elements.subtitle: Using elemental associations to create additional layers of meaning
tarot-elements.title: Tarot & Elemental Correspondences

tarot-traditions.content:
You may have noticed a little tag by each tarot deck we have, that notes something called a deck's tradition. There are 3 common traditions, each with its own historical significance.

The Rider-Waite-Smith deck, created in the early 20th century, is widely recognized for its illustrative imagery and intuitive symbolism, making it an ideal choice for beginners. On the other hand, the Marseille deck, rooted in the 17th century, emphasizes simplicity and relies heavily on numerology, appealing to traditionalists and purists. Lastly, the Thoth deck, developed by Aleister Crowley in the mid-20th century, integrates Egyptian and occult symbolism, catering to those seeking a deeper exploration of esoteric themes.

There are subtle naming differences as well as ordering differences, the most notable being how Justice and Strength are switched in Marseille and Thoth decks.
tarot-traditions.subtitle: What's the difference between Rider Waite Smith, Marseille and Thoth decks?
tarot-traditions.title: Tarot Traditions

wands.content:
Associated with the element of fire, the suit of wands represents passion, inspiration and willpower. The wands imbue their users with primal energy, for it is through them that the cycle of creation can begin. Because of their ability to bring energy into any situation, they are also associated with action, ambition and making plans.

At their worst, they can refer to situations that are filled with recklessness and lack of direction. As you follow the journey within the wands, you'll come across these themes again and again.
wands.subtitle: Creativity, passion, inspiration, willpower and drive
wands.title: The Suit of Wands
